unnormalised: Okay, so you're planning a trip via Indian Railways, that's cool! A lot of folks have questions about it, so let me share some insights based on my own experiences travelling across India by train.
normalised: Okay, so you're planning a trip via Indian Railways, that's cool! A lot of folks have questions about it, so let me share some insights based on my own experiences travelling across India by train.

unnormalised: First off, booking tickets. IRCTC website or app is your go-to. Tatkal booking opens at 10:00 AM for AC classes and 11:00 AM for non-AC. Trust me, be ready with your details pre-filled, it's a race! Agent se karwaoge toh extra charges lagenge. Consider booking at least 1-2 months in advance, especially during peak season like Diwali or summer vacations. RAC/WL tickets are common, but often get confirmed eventually.
normalised: First off, booking tickets. I-R-C-T-C website or app is your go-to. Tatkal booking opens at ten A-M for A-C classes and eleven A-M for non-A-C. Trust me, be ready with your details pre-filled, it's a race! Agent se karwaoge toh extra charges lagenge. Consider booking at least one to two months in advance, especially during peak season like Diwali or summer vacations. R-A-C slash W-L tickets are common, but often get confirmed eventually.

unnormalised: About train types - Rajdhani and Shatabdi are the fastest and most comfortable, but slightly more expensive. Duronto trains are also fast, with fewer stops. Express trains are the workhorses, connecting most cities, but can be crowded. Local trains are best for short distances within cities. Remember that train no. 12345 is different from train no. 12321.
normalised: About train types - Rajdhani and Shatabdi are the fastest and most comfortable, but slightly more expensive. Duronto trains are also fast, with fewer stops. Express trains are the workhorses, connecting most cities, but can be crowded. Local trains are best for short distances within cities. Remember that train number twelve thousand three hundred and forty five is different from train number twelve thousand three hundred and twenty one.

unnormalised: Food on trains can be a mixed bag. Pantry cars offer decent meals, but quality varies. Order food online via IRCTC e-catering, you have options like Dominos and local restaurants delivering to your seat. Or, carry your own snacks - biscuits, chips, namkeen. Chai is a must-have, available almost every hour. Don't forget water bottles; prices are usually Rs. 20 each.
normalised: Food on trains can be a mixed bag. Pantry cars offer decent meals, but quality varies. Order food online via I-R-C-T-C e-catering, you have options like Dominos and local restaurants delivering to your seat. Or, carry your own snacks - biscuits, chips, namkeen. Chai is a must-have, available almost every hour. Don't forget water bottles; prices are usually rupees twenty each.

unnormalised: Cleanliness can be an issue sometimes, especially in sleeper class. Carry hand sanitizer and wet wipes. Toilets are often dirty, so use them judiciously. AC coaches are generally cleaner. Keep your valuables safe - use a lock and chain to secure your luggage. Be aware of your surroundings, especially at night.
normalised: Cleanliness can be an issue sometimes, especially in sleeper class. Carry hand sanitizer and wet wipes. Toilets are often dirty, so use them judiciously. A-C coaches are generally cleaner. Keep your valuables safe - use a lock and chain to secure your luggage. Be aware of your surroundings, especially at night.

unnormalised: For connectivity, mobile network can be patchy in certain stretches, especially in rural areas. Pre-download movies or shows for entertainment. Charging points are available in most coaches, but carry a power bank just in case. WiFi is available at some major stations, but not always reliable. You can download RailYatri App for live train status; it’s pretty useful.
normalised: For connectivity, mobile network can be patchy in certain stretches, especially in rural areas. Pre-download movies or shows for entertainment. Charging points are available in most coaches, but carry a power bank just in case. Wi-Fi is available at some major stations, but not always reliable. You can download RailYatri App for live train status; it's pretty useful.

unnormalised: When traveling long distances, try to book AC coaches (2A or 3A) for more comfort. Sleeper class is cheaper, but can be crowded and noisy. Keep a small pillow and blanket handy, even in AC coaches, as temperatures can fluctuate. Carry a book or magazine to pass the time. Befriend your fellow passengers – you might hear interesting stories!
normalised: When traveling long distances, try to book A-C coaches (two A or three A) for more comfort. Sleeper class is cheaper, but can be crowded and noisy. Keep a small pillow and blanket handy, even in A-C coaches, as temperatures can fluctuate. Carry a book or magazine to pass the time. Befriend your fellow passengers – you might hear interesting stories!

unnormalised: Finally, remember to check PNR status regularly after booking – things can change, especially during peak times. And download a copy of your ticket on your phone just in case. And don’t forget your ID proof (Aadhar Card, Voter ID, PAN card etc.). Have a safe and enjoyable journey on the Indian Railways! Enjoy the sights and sounds of India!
